channel.title: California
channel.description: California news and features from the Los Angeles Times.

item.title: Large fire engulfs commercial building in downtown Los Angeles
item.dc:creator: Matthew Ormseth
item.description: A large fire engulfed a commercial building in downtown Los Angeles on Monday afternoon, drawing 112 firefighters to the blaze just east of the city's Fashion District, the Los Angeles Fire Department said.
item.content:encoded: A large fire engulfed a commercial building in downtown Los Angeles on Monday afternoon, drawing 112 firefighters to the blaze just east of the city's Fashion District, the Los Angeles Fire Department said.

item.title: UC clears Regent George Kieffer of allegations of sexual misconduct
item.dc:creator: Teresa Watanabe
item.description: The University of California has cleared Regent George Kieffer of allegations of sexual misconduct, finding insufficient evidence to support a graduate student's claim that he repeatedly squeezed her thigh at a 2014 meeting.
item.content:encoded: The University of California has cleared Regent George Kieffer of allegations of sexual misconduct, finding insufficient evidence to support a graduate student's claim that he repeatedly squeezed her thigh at a 2014 meeting.

media:content.media:description: WESTWOOD, CA - SEPTEMBER 15, 2016: UC President Janet Napolitano,middle, with Regent George Kieffer,left, and Regents chairwoman Monica Lozano, right, listen as UC Riverside gives a presentation during the UC Regents meeting at the Luskin Conference Center on the campus of UCLA on September 15, 2016 in Westwood, California.(Gina Ferazzi / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: California would ban police chokeholds under deal struck by legislative leaders
item.dc:creator: Associated Press
item.description: California's Assembly speaker and other key lawmakers on Monday backed making it illegal statewide for police to use a type of neck hold, a response to protests over police brutality.
item.content:encoded: California's Assembly speaker and other key lawmakers on Monday backed making it illegal statewide for police to use a type of neck hold, a response to protests over police brutality.

media:content.media:description: Assembly Speaker Anthony Rendon, D-Lakewood, discusses his support to a proposed measure by Assemblyman Mike Gipson, D-Carson, to make it "illegal to use the choke hold and carotid artery restrain tactics to forcibly detain a suspect," during a news conference in Sacramento, Calif., Monday, June 8, 2020. The proposal appears to go beyond any other state's law and comes after a different restraint hold was used by Minneapolis police was blamed for the death of George Floyd. (AP Photo/Rich Pedroncelli)

item.title: Ex-OC sheriff's deputies plead guilty in evidence booking scandal
item.dc:creator: James Queally
item.description: Several deputies have been charged for failing to properly book evidence seized during criminal investigations, a scandal that could affect thousands of criminal cases.
item.content:encoded: Several deputies have been charged for failing to properly book evidence seized during criminal investigations, a scandal that could affect thousands of criminal cases.

media:content.media:description: SANTA ANA, CALIF. -- TUESDAY, FEBRUARY 19, 2019: Orange County Sheriff Don Barnes talks to a reporter at his office in Santa Ana, Calif., on Feb. 19, 2019. (Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times

item.title: 600-gallon sewage spill partially shutters ocean access in Laguna Beach
item.dc:creator: Luke Money
item.description: The closure is in place from Sleepy Hollow Lane to Cleo Street, according to the Orange County Health Care Agency.
item.content:encoded: The closure is in place from Sleepy Hollow Lane to Cleo Street, according to the Orange County Health Care Agency.

media:content.media:description: The water was inaccessible between Sleepy Hollow Lane and Cleo Street in Laguna Beach Monday after 600 gallons of raw sewage spilled into the ocean, according to Orange County health officials.

item.title: Fontana police officer arrested on suspicion of raping 16-year-old girl
item.dc:creator: Luke Money
item.description: Nicholas Shawn Stark was arrested on suspicion of rape of a minor by intoxication, according to the San Bernardino County Sheriff's Department.
item.content:encoded: Nicholas Shawn Stark was arrested on suspicion of rape of a minor by intoxication, according to the San Bernardino County Sheriff's Department.

media:content.media:description: Authorities arrested Nicholas Stark, 28, of Fontana last week on suspicion of raping a 16-year-old girl.

item.title: Get tested for coronavirus if you've been to a protest, health officials urge
item.dc:creator: Rong-Gong Lin II, Colleen Shalby
item.description: Health officials want you to get tested for the coronavirus if you've been to a protest or any large gathering where people haven't worn masks.
item.content:encoded: Health officials want you to get tested for the coronavirus if you've been to a protest or any large gathering where people haven't worn masks.

media:content.media:description: Los Angeles, CA, Sunday, June 7,2020 - Demonstrators at Belvedere Park protest police brutality and systemic racism in the wake of the death of Georg Floyd at the hands of Minneapolis police officer Derek Chauvin. (Robert Gauthier / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: L.A. city, county prosecutors won't charge protesters arrested on curfew violations, failure to disperse
item.dc:creator: Richard Winton
item.description: L.A. County Dist. Atty. Jackie Lacey said her office will not prosecute protesters arrested in connection with curfew violations or a failure to disperse during peaceful demonstrations.
item.content:encoded: L.A. County Dist. Atty. Jackie Lacey said her office will not prosecute protesters arrested in connection with curfew violations or a failure to disperse during peaceful demonstrations.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - JUNE 7, 2020 - - A military vehicle crosses Figueroa Blvd. as members of the California National Guard leave the Convention Center after days of protest in downtown Los Angeles on June 7, 2020. (Genaro Molina/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Coronavirus deaths spike in L.A. County, with highest weekend total in over a month
item.dc:creator: Colleen Shalby
item.description: Public health officials announced 81 coronavirus-related deaths Saturday and Sunday, the highest total reported over a weekend in L.A. County in more than a month.
item.content:encoded: Public health officials announced 81 coronavirus-related deaths Saturday and Sunday, the highest total reported over a weekend in L.A. County in more than a month.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES-CA-MAY 26, 2020: Drive-through coronavirus testing at Dodger Stadium in Elysian Park on Tuesday, May 26, 2020. (Christina House / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: More protests as Floyd 'funeral' processions reach downtown L.A., demonstrators call for defunding the police
item.dc:creator: Alex Wigglesworth, Melissa Gomez, Luke Money
item.description: Protests are underway in L.A. on Monday as people continue to take to the streets to protest the police killings of George Floyd and other black Americans.
item.content:encoded: Protests are underway in L.A. on Monday as people continue to take to the streets to protest the police killings of George Floyd and other black Americans.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - JUNE 08: Pastors Dewayne Winrow and James Thomas, left to right, of Reseda Church of Christ and Fluke Fluker, right, co-founder and president of Village Nation kneel as pall bearers carry a empty casket in memory of George Floyd at the Reseda Church of Christ, one of four starting points for vehicle processions by interfaith leaders, labor, people of color, immigrants, community members, and victims of police brutality as Black Lives Matter-LA is set to hold a memorial service in Downtown Los Angeles on Monday, June 8, honoring George Floyd and demanding justice for those killed by the hands of the police. Reseda on Monday, June 8, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: How does L.A.'s racial past resonate now? #BlackLivesMatter's originator and 5 writers discuss
item.dc:creator: Marcus Anthony Hunter
item.description: Walter Mosley, Luis Rodriguez, the coiner of #BlackLivesMatter and others sketch a hopeful future for L.A. and the U.S. after George Floyd protests.
item.content:encoded: Walter Mosley, Luis Rodriguez, the coiner of #BlackLivesMatter and others sketch a hopeful future for L.A. and the U.S. after George Floyd protests.

media:content.media:description: HERMOSA BEACH, CA - JUNE 02: Several hundred Black Lives Matter protesters take a knee and hold their fists in the air during a moment of silence to honor George Floyd during a peaceful protest march from Manhattan Beach to Hermosa Beach and return at the Hermosa Beach Pier Plaza Tuesday, June 2, 2020. (Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: LAPD officer shot with crossbow during barricade in North Hollywood
item.dc:creator: Jake Sheridan
item.description: The officer wounded by the crossbow was treated and released, and an armed man who had holed up inside his residence for hours was arrested late Sunday.
item.content:encoded: The officer wounded by the crossbow was treated and released, and an armed man who had holed up inside his residence for hours was arrested late Sunday.

media:content.media:description: An LAPD cruiser sits parked at Hollywood Boulevard and Highland Avenue near the scene of a shooting in January 2015.

item.title: Massive Hollywood protest shows the staying power of the George Floyd movement
item.dc:creator: Arit John, Kevin Rector
item.description: An estimated 20,000 people converged on Hollywood for a march and demonstration Sunday over police brutality and the death of George Floyd.
item.content:encoded: An estimated 20,000 people converged on Hollywood for a march and demonstration Sunday over police brutality and the death of George Floyd.

media:content.media:description: HOLLYWOOD, CA JUNE 7, 2020: Thousands of people participated in today's peaceful march peaceful march in Hollywood, CA today Sunday June 7, 2020 against police brutality sparked by the death of George Floyd. (Francine Orr/ Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Wind-driven fire in Castaic near 5 Freeway partly contained
item.dc:creator: Kristi Sturgill
item.description: The blaze, which started overnight near the Jack Bones Equestrian Center, had scorched about 86 acres by 3 p.m. and was 70% contained.
item.content:encoded: The blaze, which started overnight near the Jack Bones Equestrian Center, had scorched about 86 acres by 3 p.m. and was 70% contained.

item.title: Coronavirus transmission rate climbing in L.A. County as economy reopens, old routines return
item.dc:creator: Rong-Gong Lin II, Colleen Shalby
item.description: L.A. County health officials are detecting an uptick in coronavirus transmission and fear the number of COVID-19 hospital patients may increase.
item.content:encoded: L.A. County health officials are detecting an uptick in coronavirus transmission and fear the number of COVID-19 hospital patients may increase.

item.title: Excerpt: Cowboys in Compton find hope and healing on horseback
item.dc:creator: Walter Thompson-HernÃ¡ndez
item.description: In his new book, "The Compton Cowboys," Walter Thompson-HernÃ¡ndez explores the little-known history of black cowboys in Los Angeles County.
item.content:encoded: In his new book, "The Compton Cowboys," Walter Thompson-HernÃ¡ndez explores the little-known history of black cowboys in Los Angeles County.

media:content.media:description: Anthony is having a moment with his horse, Dakota, on the Richland Farms ranch. He works at the ranch every day from 5 a.m. to 12 p.m. Anthony takes care of all the horses, but he has the strongest bond with Dakota. Credit: Walter Thompson-Hernandez

item.title: Column One: How do you sign 'Black Lives Matter' in ASL? For black deaf Angelenos, it's complicated
item.dc:creator: Sonja Sharp
item.description: For deaf Angelenos of color, and particularly those who are black, the language they sign among themselves is strikingly different from what's on TV. The tension is evident in a seemingly simple phrase like "Black Lives Matter."
item.content:encoded: For deaf Angelenos of color, and particularly those who are black, the language they sign among themselves is strikingly different from what's on TV. The tension is evident in a seemingly simple phrase like "Black Lives Matter."

item.content:encoded: The Compton Cowboys joined a caravan of motorcycles and demonstrators as part of a growing national movement to end police brutality and systemic racism.

item.title: L.A. County coronavirus cases near 64,000 amid protests and reopenings

item.content:encoded: County officials anticipate an increase in coronavirus cases because of both the protests and the reopening of businesses and other establishments.

Measures put in place to keep worshippers safe include occupancy limited to 100 people, mandatory face masks, and social distancing. (Christina House / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: South L.A. still bears the scars of 1992. One resident held an event to beautify it
item.dc:creator: Kailyn Brown
item.description: South Los Angeles remains mostly untouched by burglars amid civil unrest, but a local resident decided to clean the community, which has been devastated by past riots.
item.content:encoded: South Los Angeles remains mostly untouched by burglars amid civil unrest, but a local resident decided to clean the community, which has been devastated by past riots.

item.title: After five decades, McCabe's Guitar Shop owners are retiring, citing coronavirus crisis
item.dc:creator: Randall Roberts
item.description: Bob and Espie Riskin, longtime owners of the iconic McCabe's Guitar Shop in Santa Monica, are turning over the business to their daughter and son-in-law.
item.content:encoded: Bob and Espie Riskin, longtime owners of the iconic McCabe's Guitar Shop in Santa Monica, are turning over the business to their daughter and son-in-law.

media:content.media:description: SANTA MONICA, CA - JUNE 7, 2020 - - Walt McGraw, looks out from the front door of McCabe's Guitar Shop in Santa Monica on June 7, 2020. After 50 years shop owners Bob and Espie Riskin are retiring due to fears from the coronavirus. The Riskin's daughter Nora McGraw and her husband Walt, pictured here, will manage the well known westside music venue. "No way are we going to let this place go down," said Walt McGraw. "This isn't just a music making business, it's a soul making business," he said. (Genaro Molina / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: FBI looks for link between shootings of officers in Santa Cruz and Oakland
item.dc:creator: Soumya Karlamangla
item.description: A Travis Air Force Base staff sergeant has been arrested in the killing of Damon Gutzwiller, a Santa Cruz County sheriff's deputy fatally shot Saturday.
item.content:encoded: A Travis Air Force Base staff sergeant has been arrested in the killing of Damon Gutzwiller, a Santa Cruz County sheriff's deputy fatally shot Saturday.

media:content.media:description: Sgt. Damon Gutzwiller, 38, is being remembered as "a courageous, intelligent, sensitive and a caring man" by the sheriff's office. He was married with children and had worked for the sheriff's office since 2006.

item.title: This fantastical sea creature helps remove planet-warming gases from the atmosphere
item.dc:creator: Rosanna Xia
item.description: A fantastical sea creature that uses mucus to eat planet-warming CO2 has long been a mystery of the Monterey Bay Aquarium Research Institute.
item.content:encoded: A fantastical sea creature that uses mucus to eat planet-warming CO2 has long been a mystery of the Monterey Bay Aquarium Research Institute.

media:content.media:description: Close up view of a "giant larvacean" (blue tadpole-like animal) and its "inner house" (a mucus filter that the animal uses to collect food) The tadpole-like giant larvaceanâusually three to ten centimeters (about one to four inches) in lengthâbuilds a huge mucous structure that functions as an elaborate feeding apparatus, guiding food particles into the animal's mouth. When the filters get clogged, the larvacean abandons them. The abandoned filters sink toward the seafloor, and become an important food source for other marine animals. Photo handout Terms of the Agreement:The Monterey Bay Aquarium Research Institute (MBARI) is supplying the Los Angeles Times (Company) with the digital images listed above, for use in the project described above only. By accepting these images, Company agrees to the following terms and conditions:* Company acquires no rights to these images except for the specific project stated above, nor is Company authorized to transfer any individual image rights to any other person or organization.* These images are authorized for use on the World Wide Web, when/if used in conjunction with this project only.* In the event that these images are used on the web, it may remain online for as long as the story is archived. Otherwise, they must be deleted.* The credit information listed above must be printed with the images.
media:content.media:credit: The Monterey Bay Aquarium Research Institute (MBARI)

item.title: George Floyd protests have created a multicultural movement that's making history
item.dc:creator: Leila Miller
item.description: The protests have mobilized many non-blacks who hadn't yet been involved in racial justice causes. Black protesters say it's a sign of the movement's impact.
item.content:encoded: The protests have mobilized many non-blacks who hadn't yet been involved in racial justice causes. Black protesters say it's a sign of the movement's impact.

media:content.media:description: BURBANK, CA - JUNE 04: Alan Michnoff, center, at a protest over police brutality and the death of George Floyd held in front of North Hollywood Police Station. Rally was organized by Showing up for Racial Justice (SURJ), an organization dedicated to organizing white folks across the nation to show up and fight the root causes of racism. North Hollywood Police Station on Thursday, June 4, 2020 in Burbank, CA. (Irfan Khan / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Ignore Trump's hypocritical vote-by-mail rants. Protecting voters from coronavirus won't lead to fraud

item.title: 'I guess America is finally listening.' Why George Floyd protests have spread to affluent white suburbs
item.dc:creator: Liam Dillon, Jaclyn Cosgrove
item.description: Protests over the police killing of George Floyd are springing up in more affluent, white and suburban areas than law enforcement protests have before. Experts say the trend reflects a sea change in the views of white residents.
item.content:encoded: Protests over the police killing of George Floyd are springing up in more affluent, white and suburban areas than law enforcement protests have before. Experts say the trend reflects a sea change in the views of white residents.

media:content.media:description: NEWPORT BEACH, CA - JUNE 03: Hundreds of Black Lives Matter supporters march down the bike path past beach-front homes to protest against racism and Minneapolis police officers' involvement in the May 25 death of George Floyd, an unarmed black man Wednesday, June 3, 2020 in Newport Beach, CA. It was the second of four protests Wednesday in Newport Beach. (Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: ICE alleges coercion behind California hunger strike; detainee calls agency officials 'liars'
item.dc:creator: Brittny Mejia
item.description: Over the years, hunger strikes have been a tool used to bring attention to what's happening inside immigrant detention facilities.
item.content:encoded: Over the years, hunger strikes have been a tool used to bring attention to what's happening inside immigrant detention facilities.

media:content.media:description: Hunger strikers at Mesa Verde ICE Processing Center in Bakersfield captured by drone during a sit-in protest on April 10.

item.title: Grab an extra harness and leash. Know how to keep dogs safe during the pandemic

The dogs belong to an elderly woman named Riya who has multiple sclerosis. During the coronavirus pandemic, experts warn that dogs should not interact with other dogs outside their immediate family. (Mel Melcon/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: L.A. is less cautious than Bay Area in coronavirus reopening. Here's why the two regions diverged
item.dc:creator: Maura Dolan, Rong-Gong Lin II
item.description: Despite more coronavirus cases and deaths per capita, Los Angeles has moved faster to loosen social distancing requirements than the Bay Area.
item.content:encoded: Despite more coronavirus cases and deaths per capita, Los Angeles has moved faster to loosen social distancing requirements than the Bay Area.

media:content.media:description: SAN PEDRO, CA - MAY 29: A worker from La Siciliana brings out food for people sitting at a table along a section of Sixth Street that is closed down between Mesa and and Centre streets in San Pedro where seating for dining is on Friday, May 29, 2020 in San Pedro, CA. On Friday, Los Angeles County received permission to reopen restaurants for in-person dining and resume services at barbershops and hair salons, marking a new phase in the regions efforts to restart the devastated retail economy. (Kent Nishimura / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: LAPD Chief Moore under fire over looting remarks, police treatment of protesters
item.dc:creator: Cindy Chang
item.description: Los Angeles Police Chief Michel Moore is under fire for remarks he made about looters and the use of foam bullets and arrests of peaceful protesters after more than a week of civil unrest since the killing of George Floyd.
item.content:encoded: Los Angeles Police Chief Michel Moore is under fire for remarks he made about looters and the use of foam bullets and arrests of peaceful protesters after more than a week of civil unrest since the killing of George Floyd.

item.content:encoded: Anti-black online hate speech prompted students at Granada Hills Charter High School to speak out against racism.

It was the third of four protests in Newport Beach Wednesday. (Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times)

item.content:encoded: The news comes a day after the department became aware of "a social media post an officer had on his Facebook page" that included "a baton and blood on the ground," according to an email sent Thursday by City Manager Tom Modica.

item.content:encoded: On Friday, the event producer released a statement of apology and withdrew his involvement.

media:content.media:description: RIVERSIDE, CA - JUNE 1, 2020: Thousands of demonstrators rallied in front of the Riverside Public Library to protest the death of George Floyd during the coronavirus pandemic on June 1, 2020 in Riverside, California. Police allowed them to stay 90 minutes after the 6pm curfew. Those that remained were dispersed as law enforcement fired tear gas and pellets.(Gina Ferazzi / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: UCLA handling of sexual misconduct allegations against physicians 'inadequate,' report finds
item.dc:creator: Nina Agrawal

item.content:encoded: An independent committee tasked with reviewing how UCLA handled allegations of sexual harassment and sexual misconduct by university-employed physicians described its response as 'delayed, inadequate or both.'

(Al Seib / Los Angeles Times)

(Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Fearing protests could spread virus, San Francisco has set up a pop-up testing site

item.content:encoded: San Francisco has set up a free COVID-19 testing clinic for people in the George Floyd protests to ensure they haven't been exposed to the coronavirus.

(Irfan Khan / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Santa Monica mayor and police chief face anger from protesters: 'You called in the National Guard!'
item.dc:creator: Arit John
item.description: Santa Monica mayor, police chief face tough questions from George Floyd protesters: "You called in the National Guard!"
item.content:encoded: Santa Monica mayor, police chief face tough questions from George Floyd protesters: "You called in the National Guard!"

media:content.media:description: SANTA MONICA, CA - JUNE 01: The National Guard stationed at the Santa Monica Pier on Ocean Ave at Colorado as brigades of people with brooms descended on the upscale shopping district of Santa Monica Monday morning after looters spent hours yesterday smashing windows, stealing items and setting several fires. Protestors once again gathered en masse in the midst of the coronavirus outbreak to protest the death of George Floyd, an unarmed black man who died last week in police custody after a white Minneapolis police officer pinned him down by his neck for several minutes. Santa Monica on Monday, June 1, 2020 in Santa Monica, CA. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Al Seib/Al Seib/Al Seib/Los Angeles Times

item.title: Column One: In the COVID-19 unit, saying goodbye to a mentor long distance
item.dc:creator: Francine Orr
item.description: A photographer documenting the coronavirus fight at Martin Luther King Jr. Community Hospital recalls her mentor, a nun who like hospital staff embodied care and compassion.
item.content:encoded: A photographer documenting the coronavirus fight at Martin Luther King Jr. Community Hospital recalls her mentor, a nun who like hospital staff embodied care and compassion.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - APRIL 27: (Editor's note: Image for story by Francine Orr and not for generic use at this time. Mary Cooney/ photo editor) Patient Care Technician Rakeem Addison, (CQ), age 30, puts on his white gloves and his isolation gown before entering into a covid-19 patient's room at Martin Luther King, Jr., Community Hospital on Thursday, April 27, 2020 in the Willowbrook neighborhood located in South Los Angeles, CA. He is currently working on the COVID-19 Unit at MLKCH. He said he was homeless from about age 15 to age 25 years old. He said he got fed up being homeless and started surrounding himself with successful and wanted to a part of the healthcare system. He started as a volunteer. He said as a homeless person he would stay at friend's homes and then inside his car until it was towed. He also said he used to stay on the path near King Drew High School. He went to high school in Long Beach where he played basketball. He says his father was from West Africa, in Accra, Ghana. He says his family now says he is strong. He says this November it will be his forth year working here. (Francine Orr / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Newsom's listening tour stops in Stockton amid protests and calls for action

item.title: Local mountain lion gives birth to three cute kittens

item.description: The three kittens -- P-82, P-83 and P-84 -- possibly bring much needed genetic diversity to the mountain lion population in the Santa Monica Mountains.
item.content:encoded: The three kittens -- P-82, P-83 and P-84 -- possibly bring much needed genetic diversity to the mountain lion population in the Santa Monica Mountains.

media:content.media:description: P-54, a three-year old mountain lion living in the Santa Monica Mountains, recently gave birth to a litter of kittens - males P-82 and P-83, and female P-84. Researchers believe this is her first litter.

item.title: Confusing alerts and nowhere to go: Homeless Angelenos exempt from curfew struggle even more
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Oreskes
item.description: Homeless people have been exempted from the curfew in L.A. County, but being on the streets during the unrest has been extra challenging.
item.content:encoded: Homeless people have been exempted from the curfew in L.A. County, but being on the streets during the unrest has been extra challenging.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA-JUNE 3, 2020: Alex Jones, 31, and his girlfriend Maya Johnson, 18, are photographed outside their tent at a homeless encampment on 1st St. near Spring St. in downtown Los Angeles. They were both arrested and given tickets by the LAPD outside City Hall on Saturday night, where a protest was held over the death of George Floyd. Jones is holding the ticket that Johnson received. (Mel Melcon/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: 'I haven't seen anything like it': Protests spread to unexpected places like Irvine
item.dc:creator: Leila Miller, Ben Brazil
item.description: From North Hollywood to Irvine, demonstrations over the death of George Floyd have moved into atypical areas.
item.content:encoded: From North Hollywood to Irvine, demonstrations over the death of George Floyd have moved into atypical areas.

media:content.media:description: Khalil Mcleod, one of several black speakers from the community who took to the megaphone at a protest outside Irvine City Hall on Wednesday.

item.title: Amid Bay Area looting, Hayward gun store is robbed of 29 firearms
item.dc:creator: Jake Sheridan
item.description: A $10,000 reward is offered for information leading to an arrest in the theft of 29 firearms from the Bay Area store Richardson Tactical.
item.content:encoded: A $10,000 reward is offered for information leading to an arrest in the theft of 29 firearms from the Bay Area store Richardson Tactical.

media:content.media:description: The Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives is offering a reward leading to the arrest of dozens of looters who stole 29 firearms from a store in Hayward, Calif.
media:content.media:credit: Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives

item.title: In Oakland, protesters turn streets into giant dance party: 'One more song'
item.dc:creator: Melissa Gomez
item.description: Though the group was clearly breaking the city's 8 p.m. curfew, the Oakland Police Department didn't disrupt the rollicking demonstration.
item.content:encoded: Though the group was clearly breaking the city's 8 p.m. curfew, the Oakland Police Department didn't disrupt the rollicking demonstration.

media:content.media:description: Demonstrators raise their fists during a "Sit Out the Curfew" protest against the death of George Floyd who died on May 25 in Minneapolis whilst in police custody, along a street in Oakland, California on June 3, 2020. - US protesters welcomed new charges against Minneapolis officers in the killing of African-American man George Floyd -- but thousands still marched in cities across the country for a ninth straight night, chanting against racism and police brutality. (Photo by Philip Pacheco / AFP) (Photo by PHILIP PACHECO/AFP via Getty Images)

item.title: California coronavirus cases surpass 120,000; protests, closed testing sites worry health officials
item.dc:creator: Cindy Carcamo, Soumya Karlamangla, Phil Willon
item.description: More than 4,400 people have died from coronavirus-related illness in California, and over 2,500 have died in Los Angeles County.
item.content:encoded: More than 4,400 people have died from coronavirus-related illness in California, and over 2,500 have died in Los Angeles County.

media:content.media:description: HOLLYWOOD, CA - JUNE 03: Protesters walk through a residential neighborhood in Hollywood after meeting a LAPD skirmish line during march on Wednesday, June 3, 2020 in Hollywood, CA. (Brian van der Brug / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Brian van der Brug/Los Angeles Times

item.title: 'Violation of our values,' UCLA chancellor says of LAPD's use of Jackie Robinson Stadium
item.dc:creator: Nina Agrawal
item.description: UCLA Chancellor Gene Block says it was a 'mistake' to allow LAPD to use the stadium parking lot as a staging area during George Floyd protests.
item.content:encoded: UCLA Chancellor Gene Block says it was a 'mistake' to allow LAPD to use the stadium parking lot as a staging area during George Floyd protests.

media:content.media:description: WESTWOOD, CA - JUNE 1, 2020: People wait to be processed by law enforcement officers on a sidewalk along Wilshire boulevard on Monday, June 1, 2020 in Westwood, CA. Protests erupted across the country, with people outraged over the death of George Floyd, a black man killed after a white Minneapolis police officer pinned him to the ground with his knee. (Kent Nishimura / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: L.A. aggressively expanded the police force for 3 decades. Now, a political shift means cuts
item.dc:creator: Richard Winton, David Zahniser, Emily Alpert Reyes, Luke Money
item.description: For three decades, L.A. has expanded the LAPD. Now, it wants to cut back
item.content:encoded: For three decades, L.A. has expanded the LAPD. Now, it wants to cut back

media:content.media:description: Gates was praised for his innovations but denounced for his intemperate remarks and his failure to crack down on what many condemned as police racism and brutality. Related links: Daryl F. Gates dies at 83; innovative but controversial chief of the LAPD LAPD officers' union mourns death of former chief Timeline: Key events in his life

item.title: Man brandishes handgun at protester in Newport Beach
item.dc:creator: Hannah Fry
item.description: Video shows a shirtless white man pulling a handgun out of a backpack and pointing it in the air as a black man hides behind a car.
item.content:encoded: Video shows a shirtless white man pulling a handgun out of a backpack and pointing it in the air as a black man hides behind a car.

media:content.media:description: NEWPORT BEACH, CA - JUNE 03: Hundreds of Black Lives Matter supporters march down Balboa Blvd. to protest against racism and Minneapolis police officers' involvement in the May 25 death of George Floyd, an unarmed black man Wednesday, June 3, 2020 in Newport Beach, CA. It was the second of four protests Wednesday in Newport Beach. (Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: She's an essential worker, helping the homeless. But ICE plans to deport her next week
item.dc:creator: Cindy Carcamo
item.description: Immigration and Customs Enforcement officials plan to deport a 48-year-old mother of four who is an essential worker during the coronavirus pandemic.
item.content:encoded: Immigration and Customs Enforcement officials plan to deport a 48-year-old mother of four who is an essential worker during the coronavirus pandemic.

media:content.media:description: VENTURA, CA -- MAY 28: Mariana (not her real name), a single mother of four children, at her home on Thursday, May 28, 2020, in Ventura, CA. Mariana cleans a hotel, Vagabond Inn, that is currently being used by California and Ventura County to house people who are at-risk for catching the coronavirus - including the homeless population in the county - is facing deportation on June 11. (Gary Coronado / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Using tear gas to subdue protesters may further spread the coronavirus, experts warn
item.dc:creator: Rong-Gong Lin II
item.description: A petition signed by infectious disease experts says spraying tear gas causes people to cough and scream â which can disperse infectious droplets.
item.content:encoded: A petition signed by infectious disease experts says spraying tear gas causes people to cough and scream â which can disperse infectious droplets.

media:content.media:description: RIVERSIDE, CA - JUNE 1, 2020: Riverside County Sheriffs fire tear gas towards protesters after they moved a fence into the street during the coronavirus pandemic on June 1, 2020 in Riverside, California. Thousands of protesters marched through the street of downtown Riverside and police alloyed them to stay 90 minutes after the 6pm curfew.(Gina Ferazzi / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: After tow truck driver runs red light, LAPD crash sends 4 to hospital, including 2 officers
item.dc:creator: Hannah Fry
item.description: The police cruiser struck the side of the tow truck and pushed it into two other cars on the other side of the South L.A. intersection.
item.content:encoded: The police cruiser struck the side of the tow truck and pushed it into two other cars on the other side of the South L.A. intersection.

media:content.media:description: Four people, including two officers, were taken to hospitals Wednesday night after a crash in South Los Angeles.

item.title: L.A. coronavirus test sites were closed during the protests. That has experts worried
item.dc:creator: Soumya Karlamangla
item.description: L.A. County closed several testing sites or limited their hours amid protests, prompting concern that the move could could abet a second wave of coronavirus cases. Garcetti says all sites in the city will reopen Friday.
item.content:encoded: L.A. County closed several testing sites or limited their hours amid protests, prompting concern that the move could could abet a second wave of coronavirus cases. Garcetti says all sites in the city will reopen Friday.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES-CA-MAY 26, 2020: Drive-through coronavirus testing at Dodger Stadium in Elysian Park on Tuesday, May 26, 2020. (Christina House / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: They protected barrios against looting. 'Don't come here to tag up all these walls, homie'
item.dc:creator: Gustavo Arellano
item.description: On the Eastside and in Orange County, Latino longtimers stand guard over shops and their neighborhoods to fend off potential looters and vandals during the civil unrest.
item.content:encoded: On the Eastside and in Orange County, Latino longtimers stand guard over shops and their neighborhoods to fend off potential looters and vandals during the civil unrest.

media:content.media:description: ANAHEIM, CA - JUNE 03: Protestors rally on the steps Anaheim City Hall steps against last week's in-custody death of George Floyd in Minneapolis City Hall on Wednesday, June 3, 2020 in Anaheim, CA. (Irfan Khan / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: California town declares self a 'sanctuary city for business' amid coronavirus
item.dc:creator: Hailey Branson-Potts
item.description: Atwater in California's Central Valley has declared itself a 'sanctuary city' amid coronavirus stay-at-home orders.
item.content:encoded: Atwater in California's Central Valley has declared itself a 'sanctuary city' amid coronavirus stay-at-home orders.

media:content.media:description: ATWATER, CA - MAY 27, 2020 - - Waitress Karissa Medina delivers breakfast to Dan Folkner on the first day Granny's Pantry Restaurant reopened to the public in Atwater on May 27, 2020. The city of Atwater in Merced County has declared itself a "sanctuary city" from the state's stay-at-home orders and has been open for business for over a week now. (Genaro Molina / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Troubling videos capture L.A. police violence, aggression amid demonstrations
item.dc:creator: James Queally, Kevin Rector, Richard Winton
item.description: Recent protests in Los Angeles have served up a steady stream of troubling videos of police aggression and violence.
item.content:encoded: Recent protests in Los Angeles have served up a steady stream of troubling videos of police aggression and violence.

media:content.media:description: Hollywood, CA, Monday, June 1, 2020 - An LAPD officer chases a suspected looter in an alley behind Hollywood Blvd. (Robert Gauthier/LA Times)

item.title: Before George Floyd, there was Stephon Clark. Here's what his brother has learned about pain, protests
item.dc:creator: Anita Chabria
item.description: With the death of George Floyd, Stevante Clark's brother is showing young people in Sacramento how to turn anger into action
item.content:encoded: With the death of George Floyd, Stevante Clark's brother is showing young people in Sacramento how to turn anger into action

media:content.media:description: Stevante Clark - whose brother Stephon Clark was killed by police in 2018 - speaks while hoisted on a supporter in front of City Hall on Monday, June 1, 2020, during another day of protests after George Floyd was killed by police in Minneapolis.
